rows.question_text: How will this affect @global.w_srh_female_caregiver_1’s relationship with @global.w_srh_teen_girl_1?

question_text.eng: How will this affect @global.w_srh_female_caregiver_1’s relationship with @global.w_srh_teen_girl_1?

option_1.eng: @global.w_srh_teen_girl_1 may not trust @global.w_srh_female_caregiver_1 in the future.

option_2.eng: @global.w_srh_teen_girl_1 may not ask @global.w_srh_female_caregiver_1 questions or advice if she has a problem.

option_3.eng: @global.w_srh_teen_girl_1 may make bad decisions out of anger.

reply_all.eng:
Yes, all of these are true. After this argument, @global.w_srh_teen_girl_1 is likely to look for information and advice from other places (also if something goes wrong with a relationship or in her life).

She may get into situations that are not healthy or safe, and may not want to talk to @global.w_srh_female_caregiver_1 about it even if she has questions or needs help. She may feel worried that @global.w_srh_female_caregiver_1 will judge her choices or feel ashamed of her.

rows.question_text: Who should start the conversation about body changes and intimate relationships?

question_text.eng: Who should start the conversation about body changes and intimate relationships?

reply_1.eng: Remember, friends can sometimes mislead or have wrong information themselves.

reply_2.eng: Your teen might feel uncomfortable or scared to start that conversation with you.

reply_3.eng:
Yes, you will probably need to start the conversation. It is okay to feel uncomfortable. Be open and use the correct words ( for example: use words like breasts, penis and/or vagina). 

It can help to practise the conversation with a friend (maybe another friend with a teenager) or relative, and get more information from your community health worker or social worker. You can better guide your teen when you have the right information. 

It is okay to not know all the answers as well. If your teen asks you a question, you can always say: “I don’t know about that. Let me get some answers and come back to you about it.”

reply_all.eng: Check out the other options too.

rows.reply_1: Remember, friends can sometimes mislead or have wrong information themselves.
rows.reply_2: Your teen might feel uncomfortable or scared to start that conversation with you.
rows.reply_3:
Yes, you will probably need to start the conversation. It is okay to feel uncomfortable. Be open and use the correct words ( for example: use words like breasts, penis and/or vagina). 

It can help to practise the conversation with a friend (maybe another friend with a teenager) or relative, and get more information from your community health worker or social worker. You can better guide your teen when you have the right information. 

It is okay to not know all the answers as well. If your teen asks you a question, you can always say: “I don’t know about that. Let me get some answers and come back to you about it.”
rows.reply_all: Check out the other options too.

rows.question_text: When is the right time to start talking about this?

question_text.eng: When is the right time to start talking about this?

option_1.eng: When you find out they have a boyfriend or girlfriend

reply_1.eng:
It is important that your teen knows about body changes and intimate relationships before they reach that stage, so they are ready and can make good choices.

If you discover that your teen is having sex, try to share your feelings or worries in a calm way so you can find a way forward together. Anger towards your teen will make them less likely to open up with you about hard topics.

reply_2.eng:
From the age of 10, children start to enter the puberty stage and need to already know about how their bodies and feelings may change. 

This will also help them cope better with sexual feelings safely.

reply_3.eng:
Discussions around body changes and intimate relationships can start early, before the age of 9, by responding to questions a child may have. 

You do not need to go into detail – just answer their questions in a simple and accurate way that works for their age.

reply_4.eng:
No parent feels ‘ready’ to have these conversations with their teen. When your teen asks you a question or when you see a situation together that relates to body changes or relationships (for example on TV or in your community), you can use that as an opening to start the conversation. You can ask “What do you think about what we saw?” or “How did that make you feel?”. 

You do not have to have all the answers, just use the opportunity when it comes up!

reply_all.eng: Check out the other options too.

rows.question_text: How can I best keep my teen safe?

question_text.eng: How can I best keep my teen safe?

option_1.eng: I determine what my teen can and cannot do

reply_1.eng:
When we are too controlling, our teens may become rebellious and end up doing the things we do not want them to do. 

When we give our teens space to make their own decisions and guide them, they generally behave more responsibly.

option_2.eng: I keep information or bad influences away from them

reply_2.eng:
Teens get information and pressure from many different sources that we cannot control. 

It is our role as parents to prepare them and guide them well, so they can  learn how to tell the difference between good and bad information, and be confident to make their own decisions.

option_3.eng: I build a healthy trusting relationship with my teen

reply_3.eng:
Your teen will trust you, when they feel you trust them. They are more likely to ask for advice or share when they have a problem if they are used to talking to you.

Praise and thank your teen whenever they share, and avoid judging their questions or behaviour so they feel safe to come to you again and again.

option_4.eng: I discuss consequences and solutions with my teen

reply_4.eng:
To make a good decision, we have to think through the consequences. When you have a problem, have an open discussion with your teen. Listen to each other’s opinions and discuss solutions together.

Every challenge is an opportunity to help your teen understand that each action has consequences and you can work together to find a solution.

When you work through a tricky situation or conversation together, remember to praise and recognize yourselves for your great teamwork.

option_5.eng: I emphasise that pressure is never okay

reply_5.eng:
To stay safe, your teen needs to understand the difference between respectful behaviours and relationships (when we feel cared for, involved in decision making, happy and safe) and unhealthy ones (when we feel pressured to do something, uncomfortable with decisions or actions, or unsafe in any other way). 

In any relationship or sexual activity, you should never be pushed or convinced to do something you do not feel comfortable with, and you should never force others either. 

You can learn more about this in the @data.workshop.w_svp.in_text_title.

reply_all.eng: Check out the other options too.

rows.question_text: How can I help prevent  my teen from having sex too young?

question_text.eng: How can I help prevent  my teen from having sex too young?

option_1.eng: Keep any information about sex away from them

reply_1.eng:
Teenagers get right and wrong information about sex from many different sources at an early age, including school, their friends, and social media.

Knowing about sex does not mean they are having sex themselves already. Having good information can help teenagers understand sex, be clear about safe and unsafe interactions with others, and why they may want to choose to wait to have sex.

Not knowing about sex can lead to problems, for example when teens do not understand how pregnancy happens or what risks sex can have.

option_2.eng: Forbid them to have a boyfriend or girlfriend

reply_2.eng:
Your teen may have a boyfriend or girlfriend without telling you. 

If you push them to hide their relationships, they may not  come to you when they have questions or problems (about their partner or other things), and they may end up in dangerous situations without you knowing.

option_3.eng: Have an open discussion on how and why they could wait

reply_3.eng:
Teens are finding their way in life. They are looking around them – to friends and media – to figure out who they are now and what they want for their future. Because of this, other people may push them to do things they are not ready for.

Try to discuss and explore together how they could wait to have sex until they are ready and in a safe relationship, and can better understand and handle any consequences. Be calm and focus on guiding them to make healthy decisions, even if they are not the decisions you would choose to make.

reply_all.eng: Check out the other options too.
